sentence: Hopes that Greece and the EU will hammer out a deal offset earlier pressure on equities from falling oil prices, fueling a triple-digit gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and a 2015 high for the Nasdaq Composite.

Consumer stocks led the way with shares of Dow component stocks Coca-Cola ( KO ) and Home Depot ( HD ) outperforming, while the Nasdaq Composite was buoyed by a record high in Apple ( AAPL ) and strength in the biotech sector.
Most of Wall Street's opening gains were compromised soon after the open by a reversal in crude oil prices that resulted in heavy losses in the energy sector.
The move was exacerbated by comments from Germany's finance minister ruling out the possibility for a deal with Greece to extend financial aid for another 6 months.

But the downtrade was short-lived and eventually Wall Street shifted their focus domestically, encouraged by upbeat Q4 earnings and solid technical support at the 50-day moving average for all three benchmark indices.
Tuesday's economic data was mostly benign, except for a larger-than-expected increase in job openings which increased to 5.028 million in December from November's downwardly revised 4.847 million.
Tomorrow's calendar is very light with only the January Treasury budget, and the 10-year Treasury note auction.

Here's where the markets stand at the close:

Dow Jones Industrial Index was up 139 points (+0.8%) at 17,868

S&P 500 was up 21 points (+1.1%) at 2,068

Nasdaq Composite Index was up 61 points (+1.3%) at 4,787

(+) ARO Expects Q4 loss to be narrower than estimated

(-) BIOC Prices an underwritten public offering of 8 million common shares and warrants to buy up to 8 million shares at $1.25

The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
